To Hugo's theory, that the real subject ol the ‘ius quod ad personas pertinet ' is ‘capacity of right,' or the three charac- ters which correspond to the three forms of capitis deminutio (which coincides in the main with our own exposition) Savigny is more favourable, buthe finds himself unable to accept lt because lt does not account sor the facts, and therefore lachs the very essence ola tenable explanation: his main objections being that tutela has no relation to ‘capacity of right' (Rechtslahiglreit) hut only to ‘capacity for legal disposition' (Handlungsfahiglreit), and the omission of the important distinction between cives and peregrini, upon which some· thing has been already said. Il, says savigny, we look more closely into the actual contents of the first book of the Institutes, we find that it corresponds very nearly to what he calls family law. lt treats, in point of fact, of marriage, patria potestas, slavery, patronatus, guardianship (and, in Gaius, of manus and mancipium). On the other hand, the division into cives, Latini, and peregrini, important as it ia in relation to capacity oi right, is not to be found, because it belongs, in its real nature, to public lav. The most serious objection, in savignys opinion, which can be urged against his own view, is the omission (in Gaius) of klnship, hut this he does not consider fatal. Itis remarlr· able that he did not see how shnder was the coincidence between family law, as he conceived it, and the ‘ius quod ad personas pertinet' ol Gaius and Justiniau. The former is in some ways of larger extent than the latter3 thus it comprises the whole of the relations between husband and wife, and parent and child, though these belong to the latter only so far 33 they relate to patria potestas, and also the rules in respectos patronatus and colonatus, which find no place in the ‘ius quod ad personas pertinet ' whatsoever. In some points, on the other hand, its content is less. The classifioation ol ‘persons' in Gaius and Justinian is based upon two great divisions, one ol which is iuris gentium-all men are either free or slaves-while the other- all free men are either ingenui or libertini-is iuris civilis, the first of these, prominent as it is in Gaius and Justinlan, has nothing to do with family law, because the relation between master and slave is one which belongs properly to the ‘law of things,' and which, ashes been pointed out, is touched upon in the first book only by reason of the capacity of the slave, as distinct from other ‘res' ol becominga ‘persona' hy manumission.
